entities.name: FORENSIC SCIENCE
entities.description: Forensic science is a field that applies scientific methods and techniques to solve crimes and legal issues, playing a crucial role in the criminal justice system by providing valuable evidence for investigations and prosecutions

entities.name: CRIMINAL JUSTICE SYSTEM
entities.description: The system that forensic science supports by providing evidence for the investigation and prosecution of crimes

entities.name: BIOLOGY
entities.description: One of the scientific disciplines used in forensic science to analyze biological evidence such as DNA samples

entities.name: CHEMISTRY
entities.description: One of the scientific disciplines used in forensic science to analyze chemical evidence such as drugs or toxins

entities.name: PHYSICS
entities.description: One of the scientific disciplines used in forensic science to analyze physical evidence such as tool marks or ballistics

entities.name: MATHEMATICS
entities.description: One of the scientific disciplines used in forensic science to analyze data and draw statistical conclusions

entities.name: FORENSIC SCIENTISTS
entities.description: Professionals who use scientific methods to analyze physical evidence and provide expert testimony in court

entities.name: COURT
entities.description: The legal institution where forensic scientists present their findings and testify as expert witnesses

entities.name: CRIME SCENE
entities.description: The location where a crime has occurred, which forensic scientists must document and preserve for evidence collection

entities.name: SCANNING ELECTRON MICROSCOPES
entities.description: Advanced technology used by forensic scientists to examine trace evidence such as fibers or hair

entities.name: MASS SPECTROMETRY
entities.description: Advanced technology used by forensic scientists to identify and quantify drugs or toxins in a sample

entities.name: EVIDENCE ANALYSIS
entities.description: The process by which forensic scientists examine and interpret physical evidence to draw conclusions about a crime

entities.name: EXPERT TESTIMONY
entities.description: The act of forensic scientists providing specialized knowledge and analysis in court as expert witnesses

entities.name: DNA SAMPLES
entities.description: A type of biological evidence used in forensic science to identify individuals based on genetic material

entities.name: FIREARMS
entities.description: A type of physical evidence used in forensic science to analyze and identify weapons used in crimes

entities.name: TOOL MARKS
entities.description: A type of physical evidence used in forensic science to identify tools or instruments used in the commission of a crime

entities.name: MICROSCOPY
entities.description: A technique used in forensic science to examine small or detailed physical evidence

entities.name: SPECTROSCOPY
entities.description: A technique used in forensic science to analyze the composition of materials based on their interaction with light

entities.name: CHROMATOGRAPHY
entities.description: A technique used in forensic science to separate and identify components in a mixture

entities.name: DNA PROFILING
entities.description: A technique used in forensic science to identify individuals based on their unique DNA sequences

entities.name: TRACE EVIDENCE
entities.description: A type of physical evidence that includes small amounts of material such as fibers, hair, or soil

entities.name: DRUGS
entities.description: Substances that may be analyzed in forensic science to identify and quantify their presence in a sample

entities.name: TOXINS
entities.description: Substances that may be analyzed in forensic science to identify and quantify their presence in a sample

entities.name: LAW ENFORCEMENT AGENCIES
entities.description: Organizations that work with forensic scientists to investigate crimes and enforce the law

entities.name: LAWYERS
entities.description: Professionals who work with forensic scientists to understand and present evidence in court

entities.name: JUDGES
entities.description: Professionals who preside over court proceedings and may hear testimony from forensic scientists

relations: Forensic science provides essential evidence and support to the criminal justice system, aiding in the investigation and prosecution of crimes
Forensic science incorporates biological methods to analyze evidence such as DNA samples
Forensic science uses chemical analysis to identify substances like drugs or toxins
Forensic science applies physical principles to analyze evidence such as tool marks or ballistics
Forensic science uses mathematical techniques to analyze data and draw statistical conclusions
Forensic scientists are the professionals who practice forensic science, applying scientific methods to solve crimes
Fingerprints are a type of physical evidence used in forensic science to identify individuals
DNA samples are a type of biological evidence used in forensic science to identify individuals
Firearms are a type of physical evidence used in forensic science to analyze and identify weapons used in crimes
Tool marks are a type of physical evidence used in forensic science to identify tools or instruments used in crimes
Microscopy is a technique used in forensic science to examine small or detailed physical evidence
Spectroscopy is a technique used in forensic science to analyze the composition of materials
Chromatography is a technique used in forensic science to separate and identify components in a mixture
DNA profiling is a technique used in forensic science to identify individuals based on their unique DNA sequences
Trace evidence is a type of physical evidence that includes small amounts of material such as fibers, hair, or soil
Drugs are substances that may be analyzed in forensic science to identify and quantify their presence in a sample
Toxins are substances that may be analyzed in forensic science to identify and quantify their presence in a sample
Forensic scientists often testify in court as expert witnesses, explaining their analysis and conclusions
Forensic scientists are responsible for documenting and preserving the crime scene and collecting evidence
Forensic scientists use scanning electron microscopes to examine trace evidence
Forensic scientists use mass spectrometry to identify and quantify drugs or toxins in a sample
Forensic scientists conduct evidence analysis to draw conclusions about a crime
Forensic scientists provide expert testimony in court to explain their findings and conclusions
Law enforcement agencies work with forensic scientists to investigate crimes and enforce the law
Lawyers work with forensic scientists to understand and present evidence in court
Judges may hear testimony from forensic scientists in court proceedings
